Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides support for a National Academies Roundtable, the Forum on Cyber Resilience. The Forum will facilitate and enhance the exchange of ideas among scientists, practitioners, and policy makers concerned with the resilience of computing and communications systems, including the Internet, critical infrastructure, and other societally important systems. Resilience encompasses not only security in the face of attacks, resistance to degradation, and the ability to recover from adverse events but also the capacity for innovation and adaptation and the ability to absorb rapid technological disruption in a way that reflects the values, such as privacy, and needs of the infrastructure's many stakeholders. Information technology systems are deployed at ever-increasing scale and have an impact on nearly every area of human activity. Cybersecurity has taken on increasing visibility and priority among policymakers and federal research sponsors, as has the need for information and communications infrastructure that can withstand other forms of damage, disruption, and adverse events and that meet the other evolving needs and demands of those who use them. The Forum would provide a unique venue for stakeholders from academia, industry, and government to consider resilience and these other attributes broadly along with the tensions that may arise among them.

The Forum will convene senior representatives from government, universities, and industry to define and explore critical issues that are of shared interest; to frame critical questions and needs; and to incubate activities of on-going value to participants. Discussions will encompass such issues as research directions, emerging technologies, design and engineering approaches, human-system interactions, policy and social implications, education and workforce considerations, and institutional roles. Modalities would include cross-sector and public-private dialogue about goals and challenges; consideration of technical and/or policy means to achieve goals shared by system owners, end users and other stakeholders; and exploration of case studies to extract lessons applicable in other domains. The forum would facilitate cross-sector exchange of ideas among scientists, practitioners, and policy makers, joint exploration of challenges and opportunities, and enable the early identification of promising approaches to improve cyber resilience and the vitality of software-intensive systems and critical infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project, organized under the auspices of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine, has helped support an Academies roundtable focused on cyber resilience of the nation's computing and communications systems and on the strength and vitality of our computing and communications infrastructure. It has convened senior representatives from government, universities, and industry to define and explore critical issues that are of shared interest, framed critical questions and needs, and incubate activities of on-going value to its participants and other stakeholders. Co-funded by NSF and the National Security Agency (NSA) on behalf of the Special Cyber Operations Research and Engineering (SCORE) Subcommittee of the National Science and Technology Council, this award provided major support for the launch of the Academies' Cyber Resilience Forum and for an array of Forum activities including the following: 

  • Public workshops and workshop reports: Data Breach Aftermath and Recovery for Individuals and Institutions (2016), Cryptographic Agility and Interoperability (2017), Software Update as a Mechanism for Resilience and Security (2017), Recoverability as a First-Class Security Objective (2018), and Beyond Spectre: Confronting New Technical and Policy Challenges (2019)
  • In-depth panel sessions and discussions on blockchain applications and implications, security and resilience in software supply chain and testing, global navigation satellite systems resilience implications, and health IT cybersecurity);
  • Engagements with decisionmakers including from the National Institute of Standards and Technology, National Security Agency, Federal Trade Commission, Federal Facilities Council, Special Cyber Operations Research and Engineering subcommittee, 2016 White House Commission on Enhancing Cybersecurity, the CSIS Cybersecurity Agenda for the 45th President study, Federal Bureau of Investigation, U.S. Coast Guard, Department of Homeland Security, U.K. National Cyber Security Centre, Congressional Research Service, National Intelligence Officer--Cyber, and U.S. State Department; and 
  • Engagements with private sector and academics on topics including reducing cyber dependencies, the Presidential Review Group on Intelligence and Communications Technologies, best practices in privacy protection, international norms, resilience of the nation's electricity system, and trends in cybersecurity policy education.

Among the significant Forum results are the ideas surfaced in its workshops and captured in workshop summary reports:

  • Data Breach Aftermath and Recovery for Individuals and Institutions explored mitigations for large-scale data breaches. A key takeaway from the workshop is that existing remedies such as offering credit monitoring fall well short of addressing many of the potential harms, especially when data breaches occur in situations where even the disclosure of basic personally identifying or financial information may be sensitive.
  • Cryptographic Agility and Interoperabilty explored cryptographic agility--the ability to readily update, modify, or replace cryptographic protocols and suites--in response to the potential threat of quantum computers or the identification of other vulnerabilities. The workshop highlighted the difficult tradeoffs associated with agility, the need to involve a wider array of stakeholders, and global dimension of the problems such as divergent national approaches and norms for regulating cryptography. 
  • Software Update as a Mechanism for Resilience and Security explored software update in a variety of domains and extract lessons learned for cloud computing, internet of things, and autonomous vehicles. It highlighted considerations for enterprise purchasers, the policy options for addressing externalities from software that is not readily updated, and technical issues for developers and engineering managers.
  • Recoverability as a First-Class Security Objective explored recoverability as a first-class security objective to spotlight the importance of designing and building systems that allow for effective update and recovery. Participants emphasized the importance of shifting from a focus on preventing problems toward making resilience and recovery a part of everyday operations and the importance of learning from experience and sharing information within and across sectors, of focusing on both technological and human aspects of the problem, and the value of frequent exercise of resilience and recovery processes. Looking ahead, participants cautioned that significant attention will need to be paid to recovery of AI systems--including the risks of workforce deskilling.
  • Beyond Spectre: Confronting New Technical and Policy Challenges explored technical and policy strategies and options in the wake of the disclosure of hardware vulnerabilities such as Spectre and Meltdown. The discovery upends a number of common assumptions about cybersecurity and draws attention to the complexities of the global supply chain and global customer base for the vast range of devices and cloud capabilities that all computer users rely on. The workshop explored the tradeoffs among cost, performance and security and possible responses to this class of vulnerabilities. It went on to consider the challenges of current cloud architecture and assumptions about isolation as well as the practical implications of these and other side-channel risks in the context of other known vulnerabilities. It also explored the international implications including national security tensions associated with vulnerability disclosures given the international scope of the IT supply chain.
